content.text: On mobile devices, the animation in index.html pops up and starts playing like a video, requiring the user to manually have to x out of it to see the website. Can you fix this (don't make any edits just yet, I just want to know if it is easily fixable).

The user wants me to look at an index.html file and understand if there's an issue where an animation pops up on mobile devices and requires manual closing. They explicitly say they just want to know if it's easily fixable - they don't want me to make edits yet.

Let me read the index.html file first to see what's going on.

I can see there's a video element on line 377 that has `autoplay loop muted` attributes. This is likely the issue - on mobile devices, there may be browser restrictions around autoplay, or the video is triggering some kind of modal/popup behavior. Let me continue reading to see if there are more relevant sections and understand the full context.

content.text:
Now I can see the full HTML file. The issue is on line 377 where there's a video element with `autoplay loop muted` attributes. Looking at the styling, this video is displayed in a light box / "aside" section called `.hero-media`.

The problem is likely:
1. The `autoplay` attribute on the video - on mobile browsers, autoplay often triggers a fullscreen or modal experience, or at minimum tries to play immediately which might not be allowed
2. The video might be expanding or behaving differently on mobile, potentially appearing as a modal or fullscreen popup

Looking at the CSS, the video is sized with `width:600%;height:auto;` which is 6x the width - this is probably intentional for some parallax or zoom effect, but could be causing issues on mobile.

The fix would be straightforward:
1. Remove `autoplay` from the video tag, or
2. Use a media query to prevent autoplay on mobile devices
3. Or conditionally disable autoplay for mobile via JavaScript

This is definitely easily fixable - just a few simple changes to either the HTML or add some JavaScript to detect mobile and handle the video differently.

Yes, it's easily fixable. The issue is on **line 377** — the `<video>` element has the `autoplay` attribute, which on mobile devices often triggers fullscreen/modal behavior or requires user interaction to close.

The fix is straightforward:
- **Remove the `autoplay` attribute** from the video tag, or
- **Conditionally disable autoplay for mobile** using JavaScript, or  
- **Use a media query** to hide the video on mobile and show a static image instead

All of these are simple one or two-line changes. Would you like me to implement one of these solutions?
yes please

content.text: yes please

The user wants me to fix the mobile animation/video issue. They said "yes please" so I should implement a solution. 

Looking at line 377, the video has `autoplay loop muted`. On mobile, autoplay can trigger fullscreen behavior or require user interaction.

The best solution would be to:
1. Remove autoplay and let users click to play, OR
2. Conditionally autoplay only on desktop, OR
3. Hide the video on mobile entirely

I think the best approach is to disable autoplay and add a media query to hide the video on mobile devices (smaller screens), since the layout already changes on mobile anyway (it switches to single column on smaller screens at line 175).

Let me implement this by:
1. Removing the autoplay attribute from the video
2. Adding CSS to hide the hero-media section on mobile devices (or make the video not autoplay)

Actually, looking at line 74-75, the hero uses `grid-template-columns: minmax(0, 3fr) minmax(0, 2fr)` and on mobile (line 175) it changes to single column. So on mobile, the video would still be visible but below the text.

The simplest fix is to just remove `autoplay` from the video tag. That will prevent it from auto-playing on mobile and prevent the fullscreen popup behavior.

Let me do that.

content.text:
Good! I've removed the `autoplay` attribute from the video. This will prevent the video from automatically playing on mobile devices, which was causing the modal/fullscreen popup behavior that required users to close it to see the website.

The video will still be visible on the page, but users will need to manually click play to watch it. This is the standard behavior on mobile devices and won't interfere with the user viewing the website.

The user said "don't make any edits just yet, I just want to know if it is easily fixable" but then when I confirmed it was easy, they said "yes please" - so they wanted me to go ahead and make the fix. I've done that now.
Done. Removed the `autoplay` attribute from the video on line 377. The video will still be visible but won't auto-play on mobile, eliminating the modal popup behavior.
Now the animation does not play at all when I open index.html on desktop

content.text: Now the animation does not play at all when I open index.html on desktop

The user is saying that on desktop, the video no longer plays at all. They want the autoplay to work on desktop but not on mobile. I need to conditionally enable autoplay based on screen size or device type.

I can add JavaScript to detect if it's a mobile device and only add the autoplay attribute on desktop. Or I could use a media query approach, but that won't work for the autoplay attribute since it's HTML.

The best approach would be to add JavaScript that:
1. Checks if the device is not mobile
2. If desktop, add the autoplay attribute to the video

Or I could add the autoplay attribute back and then use JavaScript to remove it on mobile devices.

Let me add a script that will conditionally set autoplay based on screen size/device detection.

input.old_string:
<video style="background:#020617;border-radius:0.9rem;width:600%;height:auto;" loop muted>
            <source src="images/vid/3N Consulting Website Video.mp4" type="video/mp4">
            Your browser does not support the video tag.
          </video>
input.new_string:
<video id="hero-video" style="background:#020617;border-radius:0.9rem;width:600%;height:auto;" loop muted>
            <source src="images/vid/3N Consulting Website Video.mp4" type="video/mp4">
            Your browser does not support the video tag.
          </video>

content.output:
373→ 374→ 375→
376→
Our work in motion
377→ 381→

content.lineBasedDiff:
--- /Users/anupeesay/PycharmProjects/3NWebsite2/index.html +++ /Users/anupeesay/PycharmProjects/3NWebsite2/index.html @@ -374,7 +374,7 @@
Our work in motion
-

content.text: Good, I added an id to the video element. Now I need to add JavaScript that will conditionally add the autoplay attribute on desktop but not on mobile. I'll add this to the script section at the bottom.

input.old_string:
<script>
  // Navigation toggle
  const toggle = document.querySelector('.nav-toggle');
  const links = document.querySelector('.nav-links');
  if (toggle && links) {
    toggle.addEventListener('click', () => {
      links.classList.toggle('show');
    });
  }
input.new_string:
<script>
  // Conditional video autoplay for desktop only
  const isMobile = () => window.innerWidth <= 768 || /Android|webOS|iPhone|iPad|iPod|BlackBerry|IEMobile|Opera Mini/i.test(navigator.userAgent);
  const heroVideo = document.getElementById('hero-video');
  if (heroVideo && !isMobile()) {
    heroVideo.setAttribute('autoplay', '');
  }

  // Navigation toggle
  const toggle = document.querySelector('.nav-toggle');
  const links = document.querySelector('.nav-links');
  if (toggle && links) {
    toggle.addEventListener('click', () => {
      links.classList.toggle('show');
    });
  }

content.text:
Perfect! I've added JavaScript that:
1. Checks if the device is mobile (via screen width OR user agent detection)
2. Only adds the autoplay attribute to the video if it's NOT mobile

This way:
- On desktop (width > 768px), the video will autoplay
- On mobile devices, the video won't autoplay, so it won't pop up as a modal

The fix is done.
Done. Added JavaScript that conditionally enables autoplay only on desktop (screens wider than 768px). On mobile, the video won't autoplay and won't pop up as a modal.

content.text: I still want the video to play on mobile, I just don't want it to pop up as a modal. Is this possible?

The user wants the video to play on mobile, but not pop up as a modal. This is definitely possible. The issue is that `autoplay` on mobile browsers often triggers fullscreen/modal behavior because of browser policies.

The solution is to:
1. Keep `autoplay` on the video
2. Add `playsinline` attribute to prevent fullscreen/modal behavior on mobile
3. Remove the JavaScript conditional logic I just added

The `playsinline` attribute tells mobile browsers to play the video inline within the page instead of going fullscreen or opening as a modal. This is a standard HTML5 attribute that's widely supported on modern mobile browsers.

content.text: Perfect. I've added the `playsinline` attribute to the video, which prevents it from opening in fullscreen/modal on mobile devices while still allowing autoplay. I also removed the JavaScript I added earlier since it's no longer needed. The `playsinline` attribute is the standard way to handle this on mobile browsers.

Yes. Added the `playsinline` attribute to the video. This tells mobile browsers to play it inline within the page instead of fullscreen/modal, while still allowing autoplay. Standard on modern mobile browsers.
